qas.question: What is uncertain about the Cretaceous?
What atmospheric gas caused temperatures levels to be 10 degrees higher than today?
What was about equal across the planet?
During the Cretaceous what climate was thought to be found in areas near the seas?
What did large amounts of deposited un-decomposed organic matter later become?
What is most volatile aspect about the Cretaceous?

plausible_answers.text: temperature gradient from north to south to become almost flat

qas.question: Lower levels of carbon dioxide caused what?
The circulation of oxygen in the deep ocean may have increased during what period?
Black shale was destroyed by what during the Cretaceous period?
Why were equatorial ocean waters too cold?

context: The <a0_0><b5_0>climate<b5_0/><a0_0/> of the <b7_0>Cretaceous<b7_0/> is less certain and more widely disputed. Higher levels of <a1_0>carbon dioxide<a1_0/> in the atmosphere are thought to have caused the world <b6_0>temperature gradient from north to south to become almost flat<b6_0/>: <a2_0>temperatures<a2_0/> were about the same across the planet. Average <b9_0>temperatures were also higher<b9_0/> than today by about 10°C. In fact, by the middle Cretaceous, equatorial ocean waters (perhaps as warm as 20 °C in the deep ocean) may have been too warm for sea life,[dubious – discuss][citation needed] and land areas near the equator may have been <a3_0>deserts<a3_0/> despite their proximity to water. The <b8_0>circulation of oxygen<b8_0/> to the deep ocean may also have been disrupted.[dubious – discuss] For this reason, large volumes of organic matter that was unable to decompose accumulated, eventually being deposited as "<a4_0>black shale<a4_0/>".
